he: רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אִיתְּרַעָא בֵּיהּ מִילְּתָא סָבַר דְּלָא לְמִיפַּק לְפִירְקָא אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי חֲנִינָא אִם הָיוּ רַבִּים צְרִיכִין לוֹ אֵינוֹ נִמְנָע סְבַר לְאוֹקוֹמֵי אָמוֹרָא עֲלֵיהּ אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב תַּנְיָא וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יַעֲמִיד תּוּרְגְּמָן
text: It was related that a calamity, i.e., a death in the family, once befell Rabba bar bar Ḥana, and he thought not to go out to deliver his exposition. Rabbi Ḥanina said to him: Is it not taught that if the public needs him to teach them these things, one need not refrain from doing so? He then thought to place an interpreter alongside him, who would sound his words to the public, as was normally done for such an exposition. Rav said to him: It is taught in a baraita similarly: Provided that he does not place the disseminator alongside him.
